title: 113_s2952
content: The "Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2014" establishes the "Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking" in the executive branch. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking is comprised of 15 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Minority Leader of the House. Appointments include individuals with expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by various leaders. Appointments include individuals with expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. Members are selected based on their expertise in economics, statistics, program evaluation, data security, and database management. The President selects the chairperson, and the Speaker of the House of Representatives selects the co-chairperson of the Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment, with members serving for the duration of the Commission. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without pay but are allowed travel expenses while performing Commission services. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking is tasked with specific duties. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will conduct a study on data inventory, infrastructure, and protocols related to Federal policymaking. Recommendations will be made on integrating data for program evaluation and incorporating outcomes measurement into program design. Consideration will also be given to creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will study the integration of data for program evaluation and outcomes measurement. This includes evaluating relevant administrative datasets, linking them to survey datasets, addressing legal and administrative barriers, data-sharing infrastructure, funding for a clearinghouse, access for qualified researchers, privacy protection, and using research results to improve program design. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will submit a report to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation or administrative actions to improve program design and enhance data accuracy through interagency information sharing. The report deadline is 15 months after a majority of Commission members are appointed. Administrative data refers to information generated or collected by agencies for Federal programs. The curr_chunk discusses various measures such as service measure, efficiency measure, milestone, outcome measure, or performance indicator, as defined in section 1115(h) of title 31, United States Code. The Commission's operation and powers are outlined in section 5. The Commission shall receive administrative assistance from various agencies and hold meetings within 30 days of majority appointment. Rules of procedure will be established by the chairperson and co-chairperson with majority approval. The Commission will establish rules of procedure, hold hearings, contract with agencies, use the United States mails, accept gifts, and be administered by the National Academy of Public Administration. Funding is subject to appropriations. The principal statistical agencies will provide funds up to $2,000,000 to the Director of the Census for the operations of the Commission. The term "principal statistical agency" is defined in a report by the Office of Management and Budget. SEC. 6. PERSONNEL. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the chairperson and co-chairperson, paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff. The Commission may procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 7. TERMINATION. The Commission shall terminate within 18 months of enactment.
